snippet: Starved for cash, some agencies are offering their desirable land to the best bidder, who will build new, modern libraries or schools in the base of new developments.
abstract: Many cash-starved New York City government-financed agencies, including several libraries and schools, are selling their desirable land to best bidders; developers who purchase land make deal to tear down original civic buildings and rebuild facilities in base of new developments; strategy, which has already been embraced by two libraries in Brooklyn, provokes growing protest in affected communities.

byline.original: By JOSEPH BERGER and AL BAKER

lead_paragraph: Starved for cash, some agencies are offering their desirable land to the best bidder, who will build new, modern libraries or schools in the base of new developments.

headline.seo: Public Agencies, Needing Money, Give Up Land and Buildings
headline.main: Saving Schools and Libraries by Giving Up the Land They Sit On
headline.print_headline: Saving Schools and Libraries by Giving Up the Land They Sit On
